{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3506151,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T19:57:24.044Z","cooked":"

My team wants to simulate our robot code in tandem with a physics simulation in order to simulate how our robot would drive on the field. However, from what I can gather, within Robotpy, the Physics Engine and the actual robot code run on separate threads, meaning we can’t get the simulated motors and their inputs and outputs to interact with our robot code. Does anybody know of a library or workaround we could use to run our code as a simulation with physics?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-02-08T19:57:24.044Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":36,"reads":75,"readers_count":74,"score":195.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485710,"topic_slug":"physics-engine-simulation-in-robotpy","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/physics-engine-simulation-in-robotpy/485710/1","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3506273,"name":"Andrew J (FRC 2881)","username":"mythgarr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mythgarr/{size}/238053_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T22:45:07.692Z","cooked":"

What sort of motor controllers are you using, and what drivetrain configuration? I modified several of the stock robotpy REVlib examples to add basic simulation support.

GitHub - mythgarr/robotpy-rev-examples has both swerve and tank drive with SparkMax motor controllers. I wrote the code with the goal of minimal modifications to REV’s samples - it is NOT what I would consider “good” python code.

Additionally the swerve sample isn’t at all physically accurate - it uses what I might generously call “video game physics”. I started an attempt at integrating a more accurate physical model (from photonvision’s sample - photonvision/photonlib-java-examples/poseest/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/drivetrain/SwerveDriveSim.java at main · PhotonVision/photonvision · GitHub) but ran out of time after kickoff.

The CTRE docs include the bare minimum info for simulation - Introduction to Simulation It looks like you should be able to adapt my simulation logic (warts and all) to work with CTRE products without too much effort.

I’m not entirely sure what you’re trying to accomplish, but I’m pretty sure there’s a way.

For actual driving our own sim isn’t great at being accurate. It’s swerve, and the drive motors simulate nicely, but I’ve got the steering motors setting to slam into their desired heading immediately. Not great, but works for testing ideas in the sim. You can drive it with a controller and auton works pretty close to real life.

For interacting with non-drivetrain pieces, if you want the whole robot code to do that even when driving there’s ways of doing that within the robot code. Or, more commonly, if you only want the physics to update the simulation putting it in physics.py is great.
